arm_group.description: Neuromuscular patients with cough inefficiency requiring a mechanical in-exsufflation support.

brief_summary.textblock:
The investigators want  to demonstrate that there is an optimal expiratory pressure when
      using mecanical in-exsufflation for each patient in neuromuscular disease. This compromise
      is between the need to generate a high pressure difference between alveoli and the mouth and
      the need to avoide and superior airways collapsus.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Method to Optimize Mecanical In-exsufflation in Neuromuscular Diseases

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  man or female age18 years

          -  neuromuscular disease

          -  coughassist adaptation treatment

          -  peak cough flow<270liter/minute

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  acute organ failure

          -  insufflation contrindication

          -  pregnant women/no affiliation to a social security scheme

          -  plan of legal protection

intervention.intervention_name: Cough Assist® (JH Emerson Compagny, Cambridge, MA, USA)

clinical_study.official_title: A Method to Optimize Mecanical In-exsufflation in Neuromuscular Diseases

primary_outcome.description: Optimal negative pressure treshold value measured  for a flow superior or equal to 160 liter/minute and 270 liter/minute

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: optimal pressure treshold based on the best peak flow.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
